rsbNotes.title: Jer 41:11–44:30
rsbNotes.text: 41:11–44:30 Jeremiah is taken to Egypt by Jewish survivors fleeing from possible Babylonian reprisals.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 44:29–30
rsbNotes.text: 44:29, 30 Pharaoh Hophra (reigned 589–570 b.c.) was killed by his enemies during a military revolt; his death is used as a sign that all the Lord’s prophecies against the refugees in Egypt would come to pass.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 45
rsbNotes.text: 45:1–5 This chapter contains God’s promise to Baruch to spare his life, made many years earlier.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 45:1
rsbNotes.text: 45:1 fourth year of Jehoiakim. The year in which Baruch prepared the first scroll of Jeremiah’s words for public reading (36:1–3).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 45:3
rsbNotes.text:
45:3 my pain. Baruch had evidently suffered along with Jeremiah as a result of Jeremiah’s prophetic commission (cf. 11:18–23). See 36:19; 43:3.

rest. See Deut. 12:9; Ps. 95:11.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 46–51
rsbNotes.text: 46:1–51:64 This section of Jeremiah comprises a series of judgment oracles against the surrounding nations.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 46:2
rsbNotes.text:
46:2 Carchemish. Nebuchadnezzar defeated Pharaoh Neco at the battle of Carchemish on the upper Euphrates River in 605 b.c. and brought to a close Egypt’s political and military influence over Palestine and Syria.

fourth year of Jehoiakim. See 36:1; 45:1. The ascendancy of Babylon over Egypt was critical for Judah in her final years.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 46:3–4
rsbNotes.text: 46:3, 4 Prepare buckler . . . put on your armor. These orders to the Egyptian army mock her military pretensions.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 46:6
rsbNotes.text: 46:6 by the river Euphrates. That is, at Carchemish (v. 2 note).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 46:9
rsbNotes.text: 46:9 men of Cush . . . Put . . . Lud. Mercenaries from Africa and Greece testify to Egypt’s power.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 46:11
rsbNotes.text:
46:11 Gilead. See note 8:22.

virgin daughter of Egypt. Suggesting vulnerability and innocence, though it could be meant ironically. See its use in connection with Israel in 14:17; 18:13.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 46:14
rsbNotes.text: 46:14 Migdol . . . Memphis . . . Tahpanhes. See 2:16; 43:8; 44:1.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 46:15
rsbNotes.text: 46:15 Why are your mighty ones face down. The Septuagint (Greek) reading is preferred by many interpreters: “Why has Apis run away?” Apis was the sacred bull of ancient Egypt, worshiped as an incarnation of the god Ptah, especially at Noph (Memphis, v. 14).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 46:18
rsbNotes.text:
46:18 As I live. See Gen. 22:15.

the King. For God as King, see 8:19; 10:7, 10; 48:15; 51:57; Deut. 33:5. In the oracles against the nations, God’s true kingship is contrasted with the vain pretensions of earthly kings.

Tabor . . . Carmel. These mountains in northern Israel stood at the eastern and western boundaries of the strategic Plain of Megiddo.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 46:20
rsbNotes.text:
46:20 heifer. This may be an ironic allusion to Egyptian worship of the bull Apis (v. 15 note).

biting fly. That is, Nebuchadnezzar.

from the north. See 6:1.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 46:25
rsbNotes.text: 46:25 Amon of Thebes. Amon was the chief Egyptian god. Thebes is in the south, suggesting even deeper penetration by Babylon.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 47:4
rsbNotes.text:
47:4 Tyre and Sidon. These Phoenician cities afforded natural protection to the Philistines farther down the Mediterranean coast, though it is not known whether alliances ever existed between them.

Caphtor. The Philistines’ place of origin, usually identified as Crete.
